articles.headline: Many Big Donors to Democrats Cut Support
articles.snippet: As the G.O.P. gains an edge with spending from outside groups in Congressional races, some major Democratic backers are sitting out the midterms.
articles.abstract: As the G.O.P. gains an edge with spending from outside groups in Congressional races, some major Democratic backers are sitting out the midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many wealthy Democratic patrons, who in the past have played major roles financing outside groups to help elect the party’s candidates, are largely sitting out these crucial midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Video Hints at Executions by Pakistanis
articles.snippet: A video of executions by uniformed men sparked concerns over killings by Pakistani soldiers, who have U.S. support.
articles.abstract: A video of executions by uniformed men sparked concerns over killings by Pakistani soldiers, who have U.S. support.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An Internet video showing men in Pakistani military uniforms executing six young men in civilian clothes has heightened concerns about unlawful killings by Pakistani soldiers supported by the United States, American officials said.

articles.headline: In a Computer Worm, a Possible Biblical Clue
articles.snippet: A reference in computer code to the Book of Esther may or may not be a sign of an Israeli origin to the Stuxnet worm.
articles.abstract: A reference in computer code to the Book of Esther may or may not be a sign of an Israeli origin to the Stuxnet worm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deep inside the computer worm that some specialists suspect is aimed at slowing Iran’s race for a nuclear weapon lies what could be a fleeting reference to the Book of Esther, the Old Testament tale in which the Jews pre-empt a Persian plot to destroy them.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Signaling Tensions, Pakistan Shuts NATO Route
articles.snippet: Pakistan closed a vital supply route for the war in Afghanistan on Thursday in apparent retaliation for a NATO helicopter attack on a Pakistani security post.
articles.abstract: Pakistan closed a vital supply route for the war in Afghanistan on Thursday in apparent retaliation for a NATO helicopter attack on a Pakistani security post.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American officials pressed their Pakistani counterparts on Thursday to reopen a vital supply route for American and NATO forces in Afghanistan, as relations deteriorated after the fourth strike by coalition helicopters in a week killed three members of Pakistan’s border force.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Helene Cooper
